channel.title: Run Windows apps on Linux! OMG!
channel.description: [url=http://winehq.org]http://winehq.org[/url] Wine, a great Windows emulator! I have it installed on my linux laptop (ubuntu, dapper drake 6.06) and IT IS AWESOME! It allows you to run Windows executables and MSI's etc. Say I wanted to run iTunes... [code] cd /your/itunes/directory wine iTunes.exe [/code] And then.... [img]http://i16.tinypic.com/4h9j602.jpg[/img] Keep in mind that you would have it install iTunes first, after the downloading the executable installer from Apple.com Wine creates a folder like so: ~/.wine/ and this is your "Windows" root directory. (~ being your home folder) If you were going to install a program, it would go here: ~/.wine/Program Files/ etc. Although for programs written in Visual Basic, you have to download and install the VB6 runtime library, and I'm still trying to figure it out myself. :D Enjoy!

item.title: Run Windows apps on Linux! OMG!
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

an emulator runs everything flawless as its running windows to run the apps

wine is not complete and so not everything works but it runs the apps natively.

using an emulator u get a window with windows xp in it. from there u run your programs. its a pain. i reccomend wine if it works for ur app.

moparisthebest.com

moparisthebest.com

programming, irc, cars

got links to qemu, a small version of xp if u need it. and a guide to intergrating qemu into linux so it runs virtually natively. also links to crossover office and cedega which are based off wine

Read full topic

item.title: Run Windows apps on Linux! OMG!
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

K. So tell me more details about a “compatibility layer” vs. an emulator. I just installed Ubuntu, and I’m trying it out, then I’ll try Arch Linux or Mandriva.

Read full topic
item.source: Run Windows apps on Linux! OMG!

item.title: Run Windows apps on Linux! OMG!
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

wine is not an emulator. it is a compatibility layer. it intergrates its own versions of the windows api calls into linux. i repeat not an emulater. that is vmware or qemu

Read full topic

item.title: Run Windows apps on Linux! OMG!
item.dc:creator: @parad0x parad0x_
item.description:
@parad0x wrote:

http://winehq.org
Wine, a great Windows emulator!
I have it installed on my linux laptop (ubuntu, dapper drake 6.06) and IT IS AWESOME!
It allows you to run Windows executables and MSI’s etc.
Say I wanted to run iTunes…

cd /your/itunes/directory
wine iTunes.exe

And then…

4h9j602.jpg640×512

Keep in mind that you would have it install iTunes first, after the downloading the executable installer from Apple.com
Wine creates a folder like so: ~/.wine/ and this is your “Windows” root directory.
(~ being your home folder)
If you were going to install a program, it would go here: ~/.wine/Program Files/ etc.
Although for programs written in Visual Basic, you have to download and install the VB6 runtime library, and I’m still trying to figure it out myself.
Enjoy!

Read full topic
